# HERON

<!-- badges: start -->
<!-- badges: end -->

The goal of HERON (**H**ierarchical **E**pitope P**R**Otein Bi**N**ding) is to
anayzing peptide binding array data.

## Installation

You can install the released version of HERON from [github](https://github.com/Ong-Research/HERON) with:

``` r
devtools::install_github("Ong-Research/HERON")
```

And the development version from [GitHub](https://github.com/Ong-Research/HERON) with:

``` r
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("Ong-Research/HERON")
```

```{r flowchart_probe_pvalues, echo=FALSE}
library(DiagrammeR)

w = grViz("digraph flowchart {
      # node definitions with substituted label text
      node [fontname = Helvetica, shape = rectangle]        
      tab1 [label = '@@1']
      tab2 [label = '@@2']
      tab3 [label = '@@3']
      tab4 [label = '@@4']
      tab5 [label = '@@5']
      tab6 [label = '@@6']
      tab7 [label = '@@7']

      # edge definitions with the node IDs
      tab1 -> tab2
      tab1 -> tab3
      tab2 -> tab4
      tab3 -> tab5
      tab4 -> tab6
      tab5 -> tab6
      tab6 -> tab7;
      }

      [1]: 'Processed Probe Matrix'
      [2]: 'Calculate Global p-value'
      [3]: 'Calculate Diff p-value'
      [4]: 'Global p-values'
      [5]: 'Diff p-values'
      [6]: 'Combine p-values (Wilkinsons max)'
      [7]: 'Probe p-values'
      ")
htmlwidgets::saveWidget(w, "flowchart_probe_pvalues.html")

library(webshot)
webshot("flowchart_probe_pvalues.html", "flowchart_probe_pvalues.png", zoom=4)
#knitr::include_graphics("flowchart.png")
ret = file.remove("flowchart_probe_pvalues.html")
ret = file.remove("flowchart_probe_pvalues.png")
#w #comment this out we when knitting.
```



## Example

This is a basic example which shows you how to solve a common problem:

```{r example}
library(HERON)
## basic example code
```

What is special about using `README.Rmd` instead of just `README.md`? You can include R chunks like so:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

You'll still need to render `README.Rmd` regularly, to keep `README.md` up-to-date. `devtools::build_readme()` is handy for this. You could also use GitHub Actions to re-render `README.Rmd` every time you push. An example workflow can be found here: <https://github.com/r-lib/actions/tree/master/examples>.


In that case, don't forget to commit and push the resulting figure files, so they display on GitHub and CRAN.
